Headline: Alyssa Nicole Harris
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2023
Alyssa was a National Honor Society member who excelled both on the field and in the classroom. Alyssa was a four year basketball player who also lettered in soccer, cross country, and track & field throughout her career. She was Captain of her basketball team and won numerous honors (Most Improved, Triple Threat Award, NKY Co-Miss Hustle, Varsity Miss Hustle, Varsity Defensive Stopper, 36th District All Tournament Team). Alyssa also made a huge impact in soccer (36th District All Tournament Team), cross country (Newcomer Award, Most Valuable Runner, 110% Award, All State Team x2, All Region Second Team), and track & field (Newcomer Award, Distance Runner of the Year). On the academic side Alyssa had a 4.6 GPA while earning straight A’s all four years and was also a member of the National English Honor Society and National Math Honor Society. She was a Title IX Committee member, Babe Ruth Award winner, and participated in Spanish Club. Alyssa has volunteered in the community with Care Closet, the Honor Flight program, and basketball summer camps. Alyssa is described as ‘a leader, compassionate, positive mindset, inclusive, role model, hard worker, devoted player, always willing to help’. Alyssa ‘pushes her teammates to be the best, but also knows the right words of encouragement… will be an outstanding teacher and coach one day… her future students and players will love her’ and ‘ is one of the most admirable students I’ve ever encountered… is the epitome of a young lady and a role model… consistently goes above and beyond… her compassion and empathy are visible in the community.’ College: University of South Florida
Alyssa currently plans to major in Elementary Education.

Headline: Abraham Martin Hils
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2022
Abe was a Super Honor Roll student and a four year baseball and basketball player. His basketball team won the State Championship in 2021. Abe boasts a stellar academic record where he graduated Cum Laude, was an AP Scholar, earned straight A’s for several semesters, and had perfect attendance for all four years. Abe was voted Prom King his junior year, and voted to the Homecoming Court his senior year. He also participated in National Honors Society, National English Honors Society, National Math Honors Society, Freshman Mentor Council, HHS Organ Donation Club, HHS Investment Club, St. Catherine of Siena Religious Education Program, and Fellowship of Christian Athletes. Abe also has extensive volunteer experience such as HMS Assistant Basketball Coach, Summer Baseball & Basketball Instructor, Honor Flight of Greater Cincinnati, Tutoring, HHS Hoxworth Blood Drive, and St. Bernard Food Pantry. He also worked as a ball boy for the Cincinnati Reds during summer 2022. Abe is described as ‘a truly special young man… a fantastic student who shows an incredible desire to learn… the type of student who can change the dynamic of a school… he speaks to everyone when he enters a room and thanks his teacher as he leaves… has an uplifting effect on the morale inside our classrooms’ and ‘genuinely cares about those around him… his effort and energy were infectious… completes his work with excellence… a young man of the utmost integrity, character, and humility’. College: Northern Kentucky University
Abe currently plans to major in Secondary Education- Social Studies.

Headline: Brycen T. Huddleston
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2020
Brycen was a middle linebacker and Team Captain of the football team. Among his numerous awards he was named team MVP, 1st Team All-State, 1st Team All-Tristate, and Northern KY Defensive Player of the Year and All-Decade Team. In the classroom Brycen excelled as a Super Honor Roll student with a 3.9 GPA. He also won the Leadership Award, volunteered for the Spring Clean event, was an Assistant Jr. Football Coach, and a Moyer Elementary Hero for 2nd grade students. Brycen is described as having ‘the highest level of character and integrity that we all want represented in the teaching profession’ and as ‘an advocate for all students… kind to everyone on a daily basis’. College: Eastern Michigan University (2020-2022), Georgetown College (2022- )
Brycen is currently playing varsity football and majoring in Elementary Education.
EMU 2020 Season- Special Teams Scout Team Player of the Year, 2x Scout Team Player of the Week

Headline: Meghan V. Walz
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2020
Meghan was an Honor Roll student and four year member of the Basketball program. She excelled in the classroom as a National Honor Society student with a 3.9 GPA. Megan was heavily involved in her community and volunteered at the Take Flight Basketball League, Highlands Youth Basketball Camps, Luke Muller Golf Outing, and Highlands Athletics Booster Drive. Megan is described as ‘kind, ethical, diligent, and well-grounded… not only is she a leader on the court and in the locker room, she is a leader amongst the student body’ and ‘a well-rounded, caring, and responsible young woman… what makes Meghan truly stand out from her peers is her character and drive to better the lives of those around her’. College: Northern Kentucky University
Meghan is currently majoring in Secondary Education with a focus on English and Special Education. She is also the Director of Basketball Operations for the Northern Kentucky Women's Basketball team.

Headline: Nathaniel Roberts
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2019
At various points in his Highlands career, Nathaniel was Mr. Highlands Football, selected as Offensive Dominator, and given the Triple Threat Award. He lettered in three different sports, and maintained a cumulative 3.7 GPA on the academic side. Throughout his years at Highlands, he took part in and led both academic and athletic programs in Special Education. Nathaniel is described as ‘has a natural talent to connect with kids… brought energy, enthusiasm, and a competitive fire with him every day’. College: University of Kentucky
Nathaniel is intent on a career in Special Education as a teacher and coach, and is currently enrolled on that track.

Headline: Will James Salmon
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2019
Will personifies the student-athlete profile the Scholarship seeks to support. Twice a football Captain, and recipient of the Red Dog Spirit Award his junior year, Will's teachers, coaches and colleagues all speak of his determination, dedication and plain grit in whatever he takes on. Will is described as ‘truly embodies our team core value of adding value to the lives of those around you… a completely selfless individual who always puts others first’. College: Northern Kentucky University
He has serious teaching and coaching ambitions, with a particular focus on Special Education.

Headline: Claudia Hils
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2017
Claudia was an outstanding student-athlete at Highlands, with a concentration in soccer. She was captain of a nationally-ranked soccer team, lettered three times, and coached an elementary soccer team, all while achieving a straight A academic record and serving in numerous leadership positions in her class and other organizations, including the National Honor Society. Claudia is described as ‘enthusiastic, optimistic, and joyful- the kind of student who can light up a room… a strong desire to make the world a better place’, ‘an excellent example of hard work, determination, perseverance, and pride’, and ‘you would be hard pressed to find another young woman who treats her peers and teachers with as much respect and kindness day in and day out while still being fiercely competitive on the soccer field and in the classroom’. College: Northern Kentucky University
Claudia graduated in December 2020 Summa Cum Laude with a 4.0 GPA and a major in Elementary Education. While at NKU she held numerous leadership positions in various organizations, such as the Student Government Association, NKU Women’s Club Soccer Team, Delta Zeta sorority, and Norse Leadership Society. She served as an Orientation Leader to incoming freshman students, a peer mentor to college students with learning disabilities, and was the only student representative on the College of Education Dean Search Committee during the 2019-2020 school year. In the Fall 2020 she completed her student teaching at Ruth Moyer Elementary in Fort Thomas (4th grade with Mrs. Kelsey Hogberg and Kindergarten with Ms. Annie Goetz). Claudia was honored with the Outstanding Teacher Candidate Award for Elementary Education for the Fall of 2020 from the NKU College of Education. Post-College:
Claudia is currently a 5th Grade Teacher at Ruth Moyer Elementary in Ft. Thomas.

Headline: McKenzie J. Leigh
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2016
McKenzie was a four-year Super Honor Roll student-athlete at Highlands. She received the Presidential Award for Academic Excellence at Highlands and has the distinction of being a 2015 Kentucky Governor’s Scholar. Among other things at HHS she was a member of National Honor Society, National English Honor Society, National Spanish Honor Society, and Future Business Leaders of America. McKenzie was a three-year starter on the Varsity Girls Basketball team, receiving 5 Varsity letters and being a team captain her senior year. She was named the MVP of the LaRosas Holiday Classic Tournament in 2015 and to the 9th Region All-Tournament team in 2014, 2015, and 2016. In 2015, she received the Highlands High School David Cecil Citizenship Award by a unanimous vote from all the Varsity athletic coaches at Highlands. Combining both athletics and academics, she also received the Northern Kentucky High School Girls Basketball Coaches’ Association Division II Academic Award. McKenzie is described as ‘the ultimate team player… has the patience and work ethic that will make her a great teacher in the classroom’ and ‘treats all of her peers with the utmost respect and kindness’. College: University of Kentucky
In addition to being named a Waddell Scholar, she received the Presidential Scholarship which covers Full Tuition for four years. McKenzie graduated in 2020 with a degree in Elementary Education and a minor in Spanish. Post-College:
McKenzie is currently a 5th Grade Teacher at Ruth Moyer Elementary in Ft. Thomas. She is also a Varsity Assistant Coach for the Bellevue High School Girls Basketball Team.

Headline: 2018 Summer update from Ms. Leigh
Desc:
This past semester I earned a 4.0 while still being involved in my sorority, being House Manager for the sorority house, and Intramural chair for my sorority. I also participated in various Intramural sports and have continued volunteering at the Lexington Public Library's Homework Help Center. I am also enrolled in a summer class called Library and Information Sciences 510, which is all about children's books and the importance of reading to your children and your students. 

This upcoming semester I will be continuing all the aforementioned activities while also starting my Pre-Practicum in the Teacher Education Program since I was admitted this past semester. Another exciting thing that I get to be a part of the year, is the beginning of a Special Olympics club! Some of my friends and I were talking about how weird it is that such a large university does not have a Special Olympics club, so we decided to start one. As of a couple days ago, we are officially a club at UK!

*Thanks for the update McKenzie!*

Headline: 2018 Early update from McKenzie
Desc:
(We got an update from McKenzie earlier this year, but forgot to post it!)

I hope you enjoyed your Christmas season and had a happy new year! Since my break is almost over, I thought it is time I write to update you! This semester I received a 3.6 GPA and thoroughly enjoyed my classes. It is exciting that I am finally in classes that are beginning to tailor to my major. My favorite class was EDP 202, which is Educational Developmental Psychology, and during the semester I got 10 observation hours in a third grade classroom. 

In terms of my campus involvement, I am still very active in my sorority, and I am now both the Intramural chair and the House Manager. This semester I played on two basketball teams, one for my sorority and a CoRec team with a bunch of my friends. I have also recently joined another club in addition to the Kentucky Education Association, that is called the Elementary Education Student Association. I am very excited about this club because we work closely with the local Elementary schools and often go volunteer or have teacher panels come speak to us. I also volunteer at the Lexington Public Library once or twice a week in the Homework Help Program, which benefits children whose parents are at work or those who speak a language other than English. I work with 3-5 kids each session, from various ages, with any type of homework assignment, so it keeps me on my toes and allows me to practice tutoring in multiple subjects. 

I am very excited for the upcoming semester because I will not only get to continue all of this, but I will also be able to volunteer in DanceBlue. DanceBlue is a 24-hour dance Marathon that typically happens in February, and all the proceeds go to the University's Children's Hematology and Oncology Clinic. Last year our student body raised $1,785,286.96, and although my back issues will not permit me to stand or dance for 24 hours straight, I am still very excited to have the opportunity to volunteer for 5 hours during the marathon. 

As far as my classes are concerned, I am taking a Spanish class, an Honors class, Art Education, Math Education, and Physics for Education majors. I have a feeling this is going to be a difficult semester but I am up for the challenge. 

*Thanks for the update McKenzie!*

Headline: Mallory Seidel
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2014
Mallory was captain of the Highlands varsity volleyball team as a senior, after several standout years in that sport, including being named MVP of her freshman team. Mallory was also a member of the tennis and track teams during her Highland years. Excellent academic achievement and numerous volunteer commitments rounded out a career that led the Scholarship Committee to name her our 2014 recipient. College: University of Louisville
Mallory graduated in 2018 with an Education degree. During school she continued her great volunteer work with everything from Special Olympics to Habitat for Humanity, and was elected VP of the U of L College of Education for 2016-2017. Post-College:
Mallory is currently a 10th Grade Teacher at Walton-Verona High School. She completed her Masters in Educational Administration from Xavier University in 2020.

Headline: Richie Whitford
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2013
Richie played four years of football at Highlands, and was a team Captain in his senior year. Coach Mueller described him as 'an inspiration...with regards to how hard he worked and how well he developed and played.' His Highlands career also included the Honor Roll, the Super Honor Roll, the Spanish Club and FBLA. Throughout the years he spent countless volunteer hours for the benefit of churches and community on everything from Boosters Club fundraisers to the Soup Kitchen. College: University of Kentucky Post-College:
Richie currency works as a Preferred Relationship Advisor at Fifth Third Bank.

Headline: Brian Beck
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2010
Brian was Mr. Highlands Football three times, and received the Red Dog Spirit Award, but obviously didn't neglect academics, as he made the Super Honor Roll and received the Silver Key Writing Award. College: Northern Kentucky University
During college Brian engaged in student teaching as a part of the COST (Consortium for Overseas Student Teaching) program at a high school in the Netherlands. We are proud to have one of our scholars involved in the vitally-important field of global education. Post-College:
Brian has, at least for now, chosen a sales career in the private sector.

Headline: Brady Dowling
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2008
Brady played center for the Bluebirds football team and was elected captain his senior year. A real leader, Brady was a Freshman and Freshman Football Mentor in 2007-08, and received the Leader of Champions award in 2008. College: University of Kentucky
Brady received his B.A. and Masters Degrees from the University of Kentucky, in English and Educational Administration. He tutored students at Henry Clay High School, worked in the front office of the Lexington Legends (AA) baseball club, and did his student teaching in the Fayette County Public School System, all in and around Lexington. Post-College:
In 2013, he became the first Waddell Scholar to accept a full-time teaching position in the Ft. Thomas system, teaching English and AP English courses at Highlands. He is also Head Freshman Football Coach. Brady and his wife, Ashley, have two children, Jarrett and Eloise. We are proud to have Brady become the first of our scholars to come home to Highlands. In recalling his own formative years, Brady notes the ‘outstanding education the Highlands teachers and staff gave me in preparing me for writing and planning for exams’, as well as the lesson ‘that friends and outside influences are just as important as having a good education. The social experience I had at Highlands...made it a seamless transition from high school to college. Being a part of the football team was also huge for me; football made me mentally and physically tough while also affording me...lifelong friends’.

Headline: Sydney Hiance
Desc:
High School: Highlands High School, Class of 2007
Sydney starred at soccer at Highlands and at the University of Kentucky as goalkeeper. At Highlands she compiled an incredible record, with a goals against average of 0.20 her senior year, and was named, among other things, Gatorade Kentucky Player of the Year and Cincinnati Enquirer Player of the Year. College: University of Kentucky
Sydney compiled one of the best shutout records in U.K. history. She graduated from U.K. in 2011 with a degree in Elementary Education. Post-College:
Sydney served as a substitute teacher in the Ft. Thomas school system and coached at the prestigious Kings Soccer Academy in Wilder, Kentucky, also finding time for an International Fitness Association (IFA) certification. Sydney is currently a Channel Execution Manager for Schneider Electric. She manages fifteen Project Managers throughout the East and West coast so does a good deal of ‘teaching’ with them regularly. When we asked how she felt about her Highlands preparation, Sydney said, ‘I think Highlands more than prepared me for my college career both as an athlete and also as a student. It is hard for me to believe that I would be where I am now without the help from the wonderful people at Highlands and especially my soccer coach Nina Kearns’.
